questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Which would best describe a workload in Compute Cluster 1 attached to a logical switch port group?

discussion.content: The question is asking WITHIN cluster 1, which is not part of the transport zone, meaning no VxLAN/VTESs involved at all...Hence A is correct
The question came from the official VMware NSX training lecture. The answer is A

comments.content: I think layer 2 would still function, but there could be layer 3 issues: If you do not follow this best practice, keep in mind that if a VDS spans more than one host cluster and the transport zone includes only one (or a subset) of these clusters, any logical switch included within this transport zone can access VMs within all clusters spanned by the VDS. In other words, the transport zone will not be able to constrain the logical switch span to a subset of the clusters. If this logical switch is later connected to a DLR, you must ensure that the router instances are created only in the cluster included in the transport zone to avoid any Layer 3 issues.

discussion.content: B. Both L2 and L3 will fail. Since there will be no traffic between VTEPs not in the transport zone, overlay network just won't work at all.

--> "If a cluster requires Layer 3 connectivity, the cluster must be in a transport zone that also contains an edge cluster, meaning a cluster that has Layer 3 edge devices (distributed logical routers and edge services gateways)."

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-Data-Center-for-vSphere/6.2/com.vmware.nsx.admin.doc/GUID-5EFF202E-42DE-4864-9B60-C5FF280457F6.html

choices.D: Within Compute Cluster 1, Layer 2 would function, and Layer 3 would function.
choices.A: Within Compute Cluster 1, Layer 2 would function, but Layer 3 would fail.
choices.B: Within Compute Cluster 1, Layer 2 would fail, and Layer 3 would fail.
choices.C: Within Compute Cluster 1, Layer 2 would fail, but Layer 3 would function.

questions.question_text: What is one of the benefits of using logical switches in an NSX environment?

choices.C: The physical infrastructure is not constrained by MAC/FIB table limits.
choices.B: The physical infrastructure is responsible for maintaining the logical switch broadcast tables.
choices.D: IP subnet definitions can be migrated into logical switches using the NSX Manager.
choices.A: Quality of Service parameters are automatically configured in a logical switch.

questions.question_text: Where can firewall rules be applied on the NSX Edge Services Gateway?

choices.D: Rules can be applied on the management and uplink interfaces only.
choices.B: Rules can be applied on either the uplink interface or internal interface.
choices.C: Rules can be on either the uplink, internal, or management interfaces.
choices.A: Rules can be applied on the uplink interface only.

choices.B: VMware Tools on the Edge Gateway sends a heartbeat to the ESXi host.
choices.A: HA Application Monitoring on the Edge Gateway sends a heartbeat to the ESXi host.
choices.D: The Edge appliance sends a heartbeat through an internal interface.
choices.C: The Edge appliance sends a heartbeat through an uplink interface.

questions.question_text: How is high availability of the NSX Edge Gateway accomplished?
Which three changes to a distributed switch configuration could trigger a rollback? (Choose three.)

choices.C: Adding a new host with a previous vDS configuration.
choices.A: Blocking all ports in the distributed port group containing the management VMkernel network adapter.
choices.B: Configure the virtual machine system traffic to enable bandwidth allocation using Network I/O Control.
choices.E: Changing the VLAN settings in the distributed port group of the management VMkernel adapter.
